qas.question: What writing system combined phonetic symbols and logograms?
What signs play a significant role in the Mayan's writing system?
What is the Mayan writing system the only known pre-Columbian one to completely represent this?
How many different glyphs in total does the Mayan writing system have?
How many of the Mayan glyphs had phonetic or syllabic interpretations?

context: The <a0_0>Maya<a0_0/> writing system (often called hieroglyphs from a superficial resemblance to the Ancient Egyptian writing) was a combination of phonetic symbols and logograms. It is most often classified as a logographic or (more properly) a logosyllabic writing system, in which <a1_0>syllabic<a1_0/> signs play a significant role. It is the only pre-Columbian writing system known to represent completely the <a2_0>spoken language of its community<a2_0/>. In total, the script has <a3_0>more than one thousand<a3_0/> different glyphs although a few are variations of the same sign or meaning and many appear only rarely or are confined to particular localities. At any one time, no more than about five hundred glyphs were in use, <a4_0>some two hundred<a4_0/> of which (including variations) had a phonetic or syllabic interpretation.
